awd_titl_txt: CRI: CRD: Keeping Emulab Tuned and Humming
awd_abstract_narration:
The Emulab network testbed based at the University of Utah is a premiere facility for network and distributed systems research, used by thousands of researchers and students at hundreds of institutions around the world.  It has come to be a central resource in the network research community.  In addition to the services provided by the facility itself, the Emulab team is universally praised for their responsiveness in answering questions and addressing problems.

Emulab is not only a highly successful facility, it is software: an "operating system" to control network and distributed system experimentation.  That software, largely unchanged, is running more than 20 other testbed sites, including the DETER security-oriented testbed.

A large amount of skilled development and operations time is required to deal with changing requirements and to support the facility's users and other Emulab facilities.  This project supports a significant portion of those personnel costs.

The intellectual merit of this proposal lies in finding ways to continuously evolve the Emulab software base, while keeping it running 24/7.  Doing so is additionally challenging because separate work will be federating Emulab with other testbeds.  The broader impact of this proposal will be to enable thousands of researchers, students, and hundreds of research projects to run network-oriented experiments that would otherwise be impossible.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the maintenance, operation, and continuous availability of the Emulab network testbed at the University of Utah. The Utah Emulab site is a premiere facility for network and distributed systems research, used by thousands of researchers and students at hundreds of institutions around the world. It is available to experimenters 24/7 via the Internet, and it has come to be a central resource in the systems research community. In addition to the services provided by the facility itself, the Emulab team is universally praised for their responsiveness in answering questions and addressing problems. The Utah Emulab site allows researchers and students around the world to run scientific experiments that would otherwise be impossible.

As of Sept. 30, 2014, the Utah Emulab testbed had over 5,000 users from more than 650 institutions worldwide. Since its inception, users have run more than 168,000 experiments on the testbed, together involving more than 1.6 million physical-machine allocations. More than 320 publications have been based on experiments performed at the Utah Emulab site or other Emulab-derived testbeds.

This project supported the ongoing operation of the Utah testbed and the maintenance of its devices. During the project period, Utah staff expanded the main Utah Emulab computer cluster from 350 PCs to over 500 PCs nodes, and they added 40 building-wide wireless nodes as well. Utah staff also added multiple layer-2 network switches to the testbed, which may be allocated by users for experiments. In addition, Utah staff expanded the "programmable backplane" of the testbed to incorporate a layer-1 switch and 10Gb Ethernet, which were needed to support layer-2 and high-speed networking experiments.  Emulab staff kept the testbed running 24/7 with less than 100 hours of downtime in the past two years.

Emulab is not only a highly successful facility, it is software: an "operating system" to control network and distributed-system experimentation. That software, largely unchanged, is running more than forty other testbed sites in the U.S., Europe, Asia, and South America. These include the DETER security-oriented testbed, the NSF-funded PRObE testbeds, the geographically distributed GENI Racks, and the forthcoming NSF-funded CloudLab facility.

A large amount of skilled effort is required to deal with Emulab's changing requirements. Supported by this project, Utah staff and students improved the Emulab software considerably. They made numerous improvements in the areas of virtualization support, testbed scaling, security experimentation, node deployment and management, and network-link emulation. As of August 2014, the code base constituted over 1.2 million lines of code in more that 4,400 files.  The Emulab software is open source.

Skilled staff are also required to assist users of the Utah Emulab testbed as well as administrators of other Emulab-based facilities. This project supported a significant portion of that effort. During this project, Utah personnel responded to an average of 1,600 email messages per year sent from non-Utah users and site administrators. This included not just offering advice, but often reproducing and diagnosing reported problems in order to produce timely fixes.
